discussion.content: A, GoTo mode is L3 routing related and provider side is where the destination/server resides so its the side from which the return traffic comes from
"anycast endpoint" doesn't exist, "anycast service" does" so not D
not 100% sure, but I would follow apot with answer A

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The client endpoint uses the load-balancer VIP as the destination address to send traffic to the server endpoint. If the load balancer does not do source NAT, which set of configurations must be applied on Cisco ACI to allow only the return traffic to be redirected to the service node?
A.
✑ Create a contract with a filter matching `IP` only
✑ Create a L4-L7 device, function type `GoTo`
✑ Create a L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy with the L3 Destination set to the load-balancer inside IP/MAC
✑ Create a service graph template that references the previously created contract and L4-L7 device
✑ Apply the service graph template. Select `L3 Destination` and reference L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy on the provider connector only
B.
✑ Create a contract linked to the common/default filter
✑ Create a L4-L7 device, function type `GoThrough`
✑ Create a L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy with the L3 Destination set to the load-balancer inside IP/MAC
✑ Create a service graph template that references the previously created contract and L4-L7 device
✑ Apply the service graph template. Select `L3 Destination` and reference L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy on the consumer and provider connector
C.
✑ Create a contract linked to the common/default filter
Create a L4-L7 device, function type `GoTo`

//IMG//
✑ Create a L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy with `Anycast Endpoint` enabled and the L3 Destination set to the load-balancer inside IP/MAC
✑ Create a service graph template that references the previously created contract and L4-L7 device
✑ Apply the service graph template. Select `L3 Destination` and reference L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy on the consumer connector only
D.
✑ Create a contract with a filter matching `IP` only
✑ Create a L4-L7 device, function type `GoThrough`
✑ Create a L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy with `Anycast Endpoint` enabled and the L3 Destination set to the load-balancer inside IP/MAC
✑ Create a service graph template that references the previously created contract and L4-L7 device
✑ Apply the service graph template. Select `L3 Destination` and reference L4-L7 Policy-Based Redirect Policy on the consumer and provider

discussion.content: There is an argument about A being correct, along with E.

comments.content: vPC+ is the mode you configure with FabricPath. Can't be correct in the case of ACI.

discussion.content: BE either lacp or Mac pinning

questions.question_text: Which two actions are the Cisco best practices to configure NIC teaming load balancing for Cisco UCS B-Series blades that are connected to the Cisco ACI leaf switches? (Choose two.)

A customer is deploying a new application across two ACI pods that is sensitive to latency and jitter. The application sets the DSCP values of packets to AF31 and
CS6, respectively. Which configuration changes must be made on the APIC to support the new application and prevent packets from being delayed or dropped between pods?

choices.B: align the ACI QoS levels and IPN QoS policies
choices.D: align the custom QoS policy on the EPG site in the customer tenant
choices.C: disable DSCP mapping on the IPN devices

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
consistency in configuration settings of QoS across multipod fabric makes sense

Selected Answer: B
I agree with apot
https://community.cisco.com/t5/data-center-and-cloud-blogs/let-s-talk-aci-multi-pod-configuring-qos/ba-p/3837889

choices.B: Define the shared L3Out in the common tenant
choices.A: Configure a BGP route reflector policy for the Cisco ACI pod
choices.D: Define the consumer subnet under the consumer EPG
choices.C: Enable Import Route Control Enforcement in the L3Out policy

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It is A because in a new ACI deployement theoritically you need to Configure BGP RR

questions.question_text:
As part of a newly deployed ACI fabric, a pair of border leaf switches have been deployed to provide shared services for all tenants. The configured L3Out runs
OSPF as the routing protocol. The requirement is to advertise the routes from the border leaf switches to the compute leaf switches. Which configuration must be implemented to meet these requirements?

choices.D: Enable Export Route Control Subnet and enable Shared Route Control Subnet
choices.C: Enable Export Route Control Subnet and disable Aggregate Shared Routes
choices.B: Disable Shared Route Control Subnet and enable Aggregate Shared Routes
choices.A: Enable Export Route Control Subnet and enable Aggregate Export

questions.question_text: An engineer must allow routes learned from one L3Out to be advertised out another L3Out. The engineer does not have an explicit list of all the routes that must be advertised out, however, they know that they are all part of the 10.16.0.0/16 CIDR block. Which attributes must be selected under Ext-EPG to allow the necessary routes to be advertised out?
